unnormalised: ## The Curious Case of the Missing Aadhaar
normalised: The Curious Case of the Missing Aadhaar

unnormalised: A few weeks ago, chaos reigned in the Sharma household. It all started innocently enough with Mrs. Sharma needing to link her mobile number to her Aadhaar card, number 2345-6789-0123. She rifled through her purse, the cupboard, even under little Rohan's bed (which, let’s be honest, is a black hole of lost socks and ancient snacks). The elusive Aadhaar card? Nowhere to be seen!
normalised: A few weeks ago, chaos reigned in the Sharma household. It all started innocently enough with Mrs. Sharma needing to link her mobile number to her Aadhaar card, number two three four five hyphen six seven eight nine hyphen zero one two three. She rifled through her purse, the cupboard, even under little Rohan's bed (which, let’s be honest, is a black hole of lost socks and ancient snacks). The elusive Aadhaar card? Nowhere to be seen!

unnormalised: Mr. Sharma, ever the pragmatist, suggested applying for a reprint. “No problem, Priya! We just need to go to the UIDAI website. Only ₹50, I think.” But Mrs. Sharma, a firm believer in Murphy’s Law, was convinced this was the start of a bureaucratic nightmare. She envisioned endless queues, forms filled in triplicate, and stern-faced officials demanding documents she didn’t even know existed. Her panic reached DEFCON 1 when she remembered she also needed it for the KYC update at SBI.
normalised: Mr. Sharma, ever the pragmatist, suggested applying for a reprint. “No problem, Priya! We just need to go to the U-I-D-A-I website. Only rupee fifty, I think.” But Mrs. Sharma, a firm believer in Murphy’s Law, was convinced this was the start of a bureaucratic nightmare. She envisioned endless queues, forms filled in triplicate, and stern-faced officials demanding documents she didn’t even know existed. Her panic reached D-E-F-C-O-N one when she remembered she also needed it for the K-Y-C update at S-B-I.

unnormalised: The next day, the search intensified. The entire family was drafted into "Operation Find Aadhaar." Rohan, bribed with the promise of extra screen time, diligently checked under the sofa cushions. Their neighbour, Mrs. Iyer, even offered her unsolicited (but well-intentioned) advice. "Beta, check the temple! Maybe you left it there after praying for Rohan’s exam results!" She remembered getting a duplicate card made once, the application number was something like APPL/2023/1234567890. The memory of that ordeal was a bit hazy, admittedly.

unnormalised: Finally, after days of frantic searching, the missing document was discovered. Tucked safely inside Mrs. Sharma's old saree, the one she only wears for special occasions. Apparently, she had hidden it there "for safekeeping" after last year's Diwali pooja. Mr. Sharma, bless his heart, just shook his head and chuckled. At least, he didn't have to deal with those triplicate forms.

unnormalised: The moral of the story? Always remember where you last saw your Aadhaar. And maybe, just maybe, consider laminating it and attaching it to a large, flashing keychain. Otherwise, you might just find yourself on a comedic quest worthy of a Bollywood film, and facing the wrath of SBI and UIDAI, the date was 15/07/2024 when they realized the ordeal was over.
